Of the various sub-genre of love stories that you find in Indian cinema, the they-fall-in-love-without-ever-having seen each other is one of the rarer ones. I like this genre because it’s harder to tell a story which is is believable for this scenario. And yet, some manage to do it …

“Butta Bomma” (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt23490324) appeared to be one such movie. The last such movie I recall seeing is from the ‘90s when mobile phones weren’t prevalent and the love story was built around letters.

This one makes full use of modern tech (or at least, somewhat modern tech since some of the plot revolves around not having a smartphone with a camera) where the love story developes between two people via phone.

The first half is a simple, sweet love story where two people find each other against odds. And then it all changes in the second half …

Revealing the rest of the plot would spoil things and so I’m not going to, but all I’ll say is that it takes a much darker turn at this point and diverges quite a bit from the sweet love story I’d expected. If you want a love story, this is not the movie for you, but if you want to be surprised it might work.

How the story goes is probably closer to life than the love story (and there is a somewhat happy ending to at least one love story in the movie) but if I wanted real-life, I’d watch the news instead 😛

Machine learning can easily produce false positives when the test set is wrongly used. Just et al in
@NatureHumBehav suggested that ML can identify suicidal ideation extremely well from fMRI and we were skeptical. Today retraction and our analysis of what went wrong came out.

Here is the retracted paper: https://nature.com/articles/s41562-017-0234-y and here is our refutation https://nature.com/articles/s41562-023-01560-6. If true, the paper's approach could revolutionize psychiatric approaches to suicide.

So what went wrong? The authors apparently used the test data to select features. Obvious mistake. A reminder for everyone into ML: never use the test set for *anything* but testing. Only practical way to do so in medicine? Lock away the test set till algorithm is registered.

Side note: it took 3 years to go through the process of demonstrating that the paper went wrong. Journals need procedures to accelerate this. Also, all the good things of this were by
@tdverstynen

title: Battle Vortex Audio Show: An Early Ultima Online Podcast : William J. Purvis : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
a few years ago, i stumbled upon some 25 year old RealAudio recordings of a live internet radio show called Battle Vortex Audio Show... years before the word "podcast" was coined.

the show consisted of a couple of Ultima Online players chatting with UO developers during the very early days of the game, just after launch. the interviews were extremely raw, unstructured, and full of #UltimaOnline lore that has disappeared over the decades. these developers would go on to create Star Wars Galaxies and many other legendary MMO's.

while I was able to track down a couple of the .RA files, dozens of episodes remained missing.

that was until recently, when /u/draculaskitten found a CD-R stashed away in a shoebox. it contained a burn of every episode in RealAudio format. afterwards, the same person contacted the show's producer, Fear, who graciously provided mp3's of the entire show.

i've uploaded the entire show archive to IA for your enjoyment and game #history preservation:
https://archive.org/details/battlevortex

title: Do we misremember Eternal September?Kevin Driscoll / University of virginia – Flow

last_post.content:
Inspired by the last few months on fedi, three provocations about (mis)remembering Eternal September:

1️⃣ AOL's gateway didn't open in Sept 1993 (it was Feb 1994)
2️⃣ AOL was not the only service to frustrate USENET (people grumbled about FidoNet, CompuServe, etc)
3️⃣ USENET of 1994 was hardly a utopia (the hostility to AOL users far outweighed the disruption they caused)

This is just a kernel of an idea. Happy to hear your thoughts!

🔗 Read on in the latest issue of Flow:
https://www.flowjournal.org/2023/04/eternal-september/

“The reason why this is such a big deal is that we typically expect the inflation rate to be roughly equal to the rate of wage growth, minus the rate of productivity growth. The annual rate of productivity growth has averaged 1.4 percent since the pandemic, roughly the same as its pre-pandemic pace. If we take the 3.2 percent rate of wage growth over the last quarter, and subtract the 1.4 percent trend rate of productivity growth, we get 1.8 percent inflation.”

https://cepr.net/its-a-passover-miracle-fed-wins-war-on-inflation/
